file_content.text: I understand.
Right.
You have surprised me, Jedi.
You have the heart of a Sith. Had you been born on Korriban, you would be sitting on the Dark Council now.
It is too late to turn you fully from the light--but should your children have a connection to the Force, I will see them properly trained.
Was that a compliment or a threat?
That's creepy.
How did you take it?
The Force is strong in you. Too strong for the restrictions the Jedi impose.
Any children of mine will be Jedi!
I won't let you!
Ha. Were you true to Jedi teachings, your protest would be that you will never have children of your body.
But you will turn against those shackles as you have so many others.
Had you been instructed in the true way of the Force, the galaxy could not match your power. I will make sure that mistake does not happen again.
A Sith Lord of my blood... it's an intriguing thought.
Thank you.
He would have power such as the galaxy has never seen.
It would be my greatest honor to train him.
I now understand why your Council tries to control your pleasure as well as your anger.
Pleasure is a far more powerful motivator.
What makes pleasure more dangerous than other emotions?
Why do you say that?
Pleasure is the foundation of all desires. There is nothing that inspires so much anger as thwarted longing.
Jedi have no need for comfort or amusement. We're beyond self-indulgence.
Pleasure is for the weak.
All beings crave what they do not have. Do not pretend you are different.
What good is having power if you can't enjoy how it feels?
It makes life worth living.
Power is only one life's pleasures.
I still remember the feel of sunlight on my skin. The scent of favorite foods. The color of my first love's eyes.
To experience those simple pleasures again would be worth anything.
This is why Jedi don't form attachments. Desire unbalances you.
You're dangerous.
You misunderstand everything. My equilibrium never deviates. I feel... nothing.
See? You haven't lost your humanity, after all.
There's hope for you, yet.
Do not mock me.
The Emperor took all that away from you. Don't fool yourself into believing you can get it back.
Give up on that dream.
At least I have the satisfaction of knowing he paid for what he took from me.
Perhaps, but there is satisfaction in having revenge. The Emperor will pay for what he took from me.
I understand why your Council controls you. What I'll never comprehend is why you let them.
The Emperor was the only constant in my three hundred years of life. It is hard to grasp his death.
I have sought the Emperor's death for so long, yet I cannot picture the galaxy without him.
When I was born, the Emperor was the Empire. Everything existed to feed his whims.
He was so far above us. No one, Sith or slave, would have dared even form an opinion about him.
You served him personally. What is he like?
Tell me about the Emperor.
I'd say joining Revan to kill him counts as an opinion.
You did.
When I began serving him, I thought it was far simpler than that.
It is in the nature of the dark side to crave worship.
He made himself a god.
It is more than the dark side. I thought that when I first served him.
The Emperor was just a man, isolated by unimaginable power and the inability to trust the scheming sycophants who served him.
I was wrong. He was a plague. And I am the only one in the galaxy who understands the full service you did us by destroying him.
Where does that leave you?
What will you do now?
I do not know.
I tried to reach him, but there was no light left inside.
He was beyond salvation.
This is not a matter of light versus dark.
You're welcome. Now why are we still talking?
It's over.
Because I am caught between him and what I once was.
The immortality he gave me, it has a terrible price. Taste, smell, touch, color, emotion--I have felt none of these for three hundred years.
I do not wish to become as the Emperor and lose all tie to what once made me a man.
I was wrong. He is a disease that must be stopped before it ravages us.
I will stop him.
I'm working on it.
Then heed me.
Even the Emperor can be turned back to the light.
There is still a man inside.
You have heard nothing! He is not a man. He will not break down in tears of regret for what he's done.
Are you going somewhere with this? Because I'm already planning to kill him.
Is this just a pep talk?
Only to warn you that the Emperor is not just a man. He changed long ago.
Immortality comes at a terrible price. Taste, smell, touch, color, emotion--the Emperor and I experience none of these things.
We are no longer mortal. When you face the Emperor, do not forget that.
And now he's worm food.
He doesn't matter now.
He lived more than a thousand years. Even to me, that is almost unthinkable.
The cost of immortality is high. To live this long, I have sacrificed all ability to feel. Touch, taste, smell, color, emotion. I have not experienced these in centuries.
It is no wonder the Emperor lost all ties to other beings.
It has been... enlightening to spend so much time among you and your Jedi.
For three hundred years, I have spoken to no one but Sith. And they do not change.
They are the same on Korriban now as in my childhood. The same tricks, the same fights, the same groveling and mind control.
Was that almost a compliment?
But you've learned from us?
What reward would they get if they moved out of lockstep? A stab in the back.
They are scared to try.
Most likely. Sith traditions are powerful... but very specific. Sometimes it takes an outsider to open our eyes to new facets of the Force.
I don't like it when you get nostalgic.
What are you talking about?
I am only surprised that I have learned the most of the Force from a Jedi.
Revan taught me to be effective when I became the Emperor's Wrath.
And now I have learned as much from you.
You have opened my eyes, as well.
And I from you.
And here I thought you weren't listening....
Your people have always underestimated the strength of the light side of the Force.
It is the power of the light.
I have nothing to learn from the light side!
There may be powers you Jedi have mastered, but they do not require that I weep and beat my brow and hide behind the Council's skirts to achieve them!
No more than what I learned from Revan.
I know what you did to your last teacher.
Was that a threat?
Indeed you do.
It is always a dangerous time, no, when the pupil begins to exceed the master?
The Emperor is dead at your hand, Jedi.
Yet you do not follow up on your victory. Any Sith would have seized the throne by now!
Even Revan and the Jedi Exile would have been hard-pressed to resist so tempting a target.
Who are you talking about?
Who?
It is astonishing what you accomplish with so little knowledge. Revan caused your Jedi Civil War, centuries ago.
He was even a Dark Lord for a time, but turned back to the light. The Jedi Exile was his protege, and partner in his quest to kill the Emperor.
You think I could... take the Emperor's place?
Take the throne?
Perhaps I should not have sown such thoughts. They will be difficult to weed out now, no? Even for the scion of the Jedi?
You remind me of Revan. He always had more darkness in him than the Jedi Exile.
I do not know how more to prepare you to face the Emperor.
What has your training been?
All I know of Jedi ways is from Revan. Surely they have changed in three hundred years.
How does someone become the Emperor's Wrath?
I'd rather hear about you.
There has only ever been one.
My training as a Sith was not far different than Korriban today.
I am prepared. I need nothing more from you.
My training is sufficient.
You do not lack for confidence, Jedi.
Revan and the Exile were much like you.
They truly believed that they could destroy the Dark Lord. I believed them, too.
Not as much as you'd think.
They haven't changed.
That is the great failing of both our peoples. We do not change.
When I step onto Korriban, I'm always surprised to see the same training I saw three centuries ago.
Only my visions set me apart, made them bring me before the Emperor. In his presence, I first saw who he was and what he planned.
You still chose to serve him?
What did you do?
I chose to live. Long enough to find one who could defeat him.
It must have taken great will to conceal such thoughts.
He didn't notice?
Showing anything but submission would have been my death.
You should have cut his throat, saved us all a lot of trouble.
I would have killed him then.
I would have been rent to pieces before my hand touched the hilt of my lightsaber.
I alone could not defeat him, so I chose to wait for one who could.
I thought Revan and the Jedi Exile were my chance.
Revan and the Jedi Exile are legends. What were they like?
Tell me about them.
It should not have surprised anyone that Revan turned Sith. He knew you cannot fight the dark side without understanding it.
The Exile was harder to read. Even with all she had done, she never trusted herself. With Revan, she was his student again.
That was three hundred years ago. Obviously, it didn't work out.
What happened?
I hoped it would.
I met Revan. He says you turned against him.
But you betrayed them.
I turned to them. As my only hope of defeating the Emperor.
I was their eyes and ears in the Sith Academy. Their most trusted ally.
I liked them. I would have served them, but my vision told me they would fail. I cut down the Exile and brought Revan to the Emperor as a gift.
Is that what you're planning to do to me?
But I should trust you?
You have killed the Emperor. You were all that I saw in my vision.
If you are not the one who will stop the Emperor's madness, then I will await the one who will.
You regret betraying them. There is room in the Force to forgive even such heinous crimes.
You can still be redeemed.
I do not seek forgiveness.
Is that when he made you his executioner?
I guess he liked it?
The only way to live long enough to find the Jedi who would kill the Emperor--to find you--was to convince him to trust me.
He took my offering and gave me a place at his side. He gave me immortality.
It was a gift. But not without its price....
What does any of this matter?
This is ancient history.
Perhaps it does not.
When you have lived centuries, you see that everything is a pattern that grows out of itself. Sometimes you can no longer see the trees, only the roots.
It is the smallest part of the price of immortality.
Your people speaking of the Empire sound like a distorted echo.
When I was born, we thought the rest of the galaxy to be mystery and legend.
We had been alone for a thousand years.
What was it like? I can't even imagine.
Tell me about that time.
We were what you made us.
If we had known, the Jedi would not have let the Emperor hold you like that.
We should have helped you.
Jedi! Do you think we waited for rescue? The Jedi destroyed us.
In my youth, Jedi were how you threatened errant children. "Obey your masters or the Jedi will obliterate you."
For thousands of years, we had total control of a hundred star systems. Then the Jedi drove us to the farthest fringe of the galaxy.
The Emperor had subjugated thousands of species. Every non-Force user was enslaved!
It was a reign of terror.
They were safe and served to their own capability.
That was generations ago. Do people really still care?
Sore subject?
Did your people still care to fear us when we re-emerged?
You're in Republic space now. That's skirting dangerous ground, talking like that.
Drop the propaganda.
This is hardly worth debating. I gain nothing from understanding how your Republic's fools view the galaxy.
I am surprised that once your Council finishes its brainwashing, any Jedi has a spine left to oppose the Emperor.
Perhaps you are young enough to still cultivate the strength of the Sith.
If you came here to turn me to the dark side, you'll be disappointed.
I will never be Sith!
I came to defeat the Emperor, and we have done that.
I came to defeat the Emperor.
Turning you to the dark side is purely for my own amusement.
Revan, the Exile and I were all Jedi-trained. We all resisted the Emperor. What Sith have done so?
Jedi have our own strength.
That was... a surprise. In three centuries, I expected to see one test his strength against the Dark Lord....
But those strong enough to challenge him are killed young, or co-opted into the Dark Council.
Perhaps you are right. Jedi strengths are different... not necessarily lesser.
I'm open to Sith tricks. What have you got?
What can you teach me?
The dark side is no trick, Jedi.
When you release the control the Jedi Council has drilled into you, when you feel anger in your every connection to the Force....
When you accept that a woman must use any means necessary to prove her strength....
When you can accept that a man of authority must use any means necessary to achieve his ends....
Then you will have discovered the dark side.
You're here to be useful. Not to chat.
Spare me.
I am impressed the Jedi allowed you to graduate their ranks with such a... pragmatic outlook.
Most would be busy trying to sell me their vision of the light side.
I'm glad you realize I'm not buying.
I did not think you would speak to me willingly, Jedi.
Now that our... alliance of convenience is no longer necessary.
Will you abandon me, then?
What will you do now?
If we are to remain allies, Jedi, what is your cause?
Right now, the jackals of the Empire snap at each other over the corpse you left them.
Has your time among Jedi opened your eyes, Sith?
I was hoping you've changed.
Has your time with me removed your Jedi blinders?
Consider your path, Jedi, before you dismiss mine.
Alliance nothing! You work for me.
You're mine, Sith.
Just as I would have said it, Jedi.
But if I am to work for you, you must strive towards something.
Perhaps together, we can fill the void on the Emperor's throne....
I thank you for your trust, Jedi.
I might not have given mine so freely were our positions reversed.
The light is always waiting.
It is the Jedi way.
I'm not here for your Jedi sermons.
I'll hear you out, but nothing more.
I don't trust you.
We work well together. In time, you will believe me.
Until the Emperor's death, we are allies. Not friends.
I need you... for now.
Agreed.
I understand you do not trust me.
But were the Emperor to find me here, he would subject me to a thousand years of torture.
You have no need of this collar to control me.
Tell me more about this vision. What makes someone like you bow to me?
Why are you here?
Fine. The collar can come off. But I'm not letting you out of my sight.
I will remove it.
Thank you.
Who wouldn't want the Emperor's Wrath on a chain?
I like it on you.
Perhaps there is less difference between Jedi and Sith than I was taught.
I will speak of my vision in detail to your Council. Suffice it to say, I have long opposed my lord Emperor.
As I told your Council, the Emperor's plan is not to rule the galaxy, but to consume it. I've devoted centuries to stopping him.
For a time, I worked with the greatest of your Jedi heroes--Revan and the Jedi Exile. But they did not have the strength to complete their task.
Revan? Jedi Exile? Should I know what you're talking about?
Who?
Revan was both Jedi Master and Sith Lord. His student, the Exile, defeated the Sith triumvirate. They were your greatest heroes. I hoped to help them kill my lord Emperor.
That's quite a claim.
You knew Revan?
You will find no proof. I hid my association with them well. Nonetheless, I was their ally in the shadows, helping them oppose my lord Emperor.
You're wandering. Talk about the vision.
Forget the history lesson.
Revan and the Jedi Exile were some of the Republic's greatest heroes. I had hoped to work with them, to aid their quest to kill my lord Emperor.
Until my vision: Jedi, shining with the Force, lined up to destroy him. All were swept aside. Revan and the Exile were cast at my feet.
Then out of the shadows, one Jedi emerged to cut the Emperor down. That Jedi wore your face.
I hadn't even been born yet.
Wasn't this centuries ago?
I waited three hundred years for your birth. When I saw your face on Quesh....
If the hopes of so many rest with me, I will do my best to honor them.
I will do my best.
If you succeed, there will truly be a void left to fill.
Doesn't give me much to go on.
That's it?
It is a vision, Jedi, not a battle plan.
In the vision, I bowed to you and took a crown from the Emperor's head.
It ended when you held his power in your hands.
There are things you should know. Tell me when you are ready to hear them.
There are things we should speak of. In private.
There is no more to be said.
I follow you for what you do, not what you say.
You're wise to keep such close tabs on me.
The Force is strong in you. Too strong for the restrictions the Jedi impose.
I understand why your Council controls you. What I'll never comprehend is why you let them.
Perhaps you are young enough to still cultivate the strength of the Sith.
I will always be Sith--but that does not mean we can't work together.
Reckonings arrive at their own pace. No need to rush them.
We have no time to waste. Be done with this.
